body: Upgrade Syncthing on the mac: Since v1.9.0 Syncthing can handle case-insensitive filesystems. And a lot of other bugs were fixed (though none that deleted files). As far as I remember mac is sort of hybrid when it comes to case-sensitivity, but basically case-insensitive, so this is likely relevant. I'll close the ticket - feel free to reopen if you can reproduce with an up-to-date Syncthing.
I've upgraded to v1.14.0 on the mac. The behavior is identical.
Can you enable model and db debug tracing (env var `STTRACE=model,db` or in web ui under actions > logs), reproduce again and share the logs please.

The other side appears to be running with what it thinks is a case sensitive filesystem? That is, it feels like the `caseSensitiveFS` options is set to true on one of the sides, even though this doesn't match the underlying filesystem. Otherwise I don't know what's going on.

Thanks for the logs. Looks all good on this side. So what Jakob wrote or given the other device is an android some weird android filesystem shenanigans. I wouldn't even be surprised anymore if android at first pretends the new file has been written successfully, then decides that isn't actually allowed, and thus on a subsequent scan the file is gone. To investigate that you'd need to provide logs for the same scenario also including the `fs` debugging facility from the android device.

I'm having a hard time getting the relevant logs from the Android device. The Syncthing app on the Samsung seems to only return a static log within a narrow timerange. Whenever I try to load the logs again, the previous log lines are gone.

Can you explain how to get the full log from the device so I can share?

Activating the necessary debugging facility works, right? (web ui: actions > logs) Then you'll probably have to use `adb` - the logs presented by the app being truncated is a know problem. After activating the debug facilities and before starting to reproduce, run e.g. `adb logcat > android-log.txt` and abort that when done. It will include non-syncthing logs as well - that can be filtered out.

This is the relevant output of `adb logcat | grep Syncthing` (please note, the steps this time were `touch foo.txt`, then `mv foo.txt FOO.txt` instead of the other way around):

Thanks for the logs.

The rename is detected, it is also detected that the FS is case-insensitive, which isn't a problem (we rename via a temporary file):

```
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: sendreceive/Bas@0x4000260e00 taking rename shortcut foo.txt -> FOO.txt
[...]
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: folder_sendrecv.go:956 basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Lstat FOO.txt <nil> given name "FOO.txt" differs from name in filesystem "foo.txt"
[...]
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Watch: Sending foo.txt remove
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: osutil.go:33 basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Rename foo.txt .syncthing.FOO.txt.tmp <nil>
[...]
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Watch: Sending FOO.txt non-remove
03-11 13:50:54 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: osutil.go:33 basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Rename .syncthing.FOO.txt.tmp FOO.txt <nil>
[...]
```

All good so far, the rename is done and accounted for in the db. The generated filesystem events are consistent with the operations happening. What happens then is weird:

```
03-11 13:50:59 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Watch: Sending FOO.txt remove
[...]
03-11 13:51:09 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: sendreceive/Bas@0x4000260e00 scanning
[...]
03-11 13:51:09 [JCMZZ] DEBUG: osutil.go:134 basic /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas Lstat FOO.txt <nil> lstat /storage/emulated/0/Sync/Bas/FOO.txt: no such file or directory
```

There's no operation done by Syncthing after the rename, but there is an event from the filesystem watcher 5s after renaming that says that `FOO.txt` got deleted. And the scan happening afterwards confirms it.

I cannot reproduce this between linux and windows.

It looks like either the rename fails, but android doesn't report an error, or something deletes the new file after the rename. In any case there's nothing left to debug from Syncthing's side. To see what's actually going on you'd need to take an strace. Which I expected to be hopeless on android, but apparently it isn't: https://source.android.com/devices/tech/debug/strace  

Usually I'd close this now, as there's no indication Syncthing is doing anything wrong, however the outcome here (data silently deleted) is scary regardless.

That commit unfortunately doesn't fix this: On a first superficial look at the logs I thought it was the culprit, and created the commit. Later on I forgot to adjust the commit message. So reopening, sadly.

I can't reproduce this with my combination:
`v1.14.0, macOS (64-bit Intel/AMD)` on a case-insensitive FS as well and `v1.14.0, Linux (64-bit Intel/AMD)` on XFS.
Afterwards I still have and see a `foo.txt` on both clients This is also represented in the same "Global State" as "Local State" (file count)

rename.from: Rename with different case triggers delete
rename.to: Rename with different case triggers delete on android

body:
> There's no operation done by Syncthing after the rename, but there is an event from the filesystem watcher 5s after renaming that says that FOO.txt got deleted. And the scan happening afterwards confirms it.
> I cannot reproduce this between linux and windows.

This looks like it's not on our side, and even if it is it's not something we'll be able to fix without being able to reproduce it...
